content.raw:
There's a slight difference in behaviour when inserting links and when inserting models:

1. Click on the cylinder shape

1. Before clicking on the scene to insert it, select the settings tab - the cylinder link is not there yet

1. Only when you click on the scene `link_0` shows up on the list.

If you do the same process for a nested model, on step 2 you'll see that the model name appears on the list  even before you click on the scene.
content.html:
There's a slight difference in behaviour when inserting links and when inserting models:

  1. Click on the cylinder shape

  2. Before clicking on the scene to insert it, select the settings tab - the cylinder link is not there yet

  3. Only when you click on the scene link_0 shows up on the list.

If you do the same process for a nested model, on step 2 you'll see that the model name appears on the list even before you click on the scene.

pullrequest.title: Add Insert tab to model editor

content.raw:
Planes are not supported in the model editor yet. We've disabled the editing option for planes if you right-click an existing model. But with this pull request, it is possible to insert planes from the panel, resulting in several errors like this:

~~~
[Err] [ConfigWidget.cc:2374] Error updating Geometry Config widget: 'plane' not found
~~~

I've ticketed issue #1769
content.html:
Planes are not supported in the model editor yet. We've disabled the editing option for planes if you right-click an existing model. But with this pull request, it is possible to insert planes from the panel, resulting in several errors like this:

[Err] [ConfigWidget.cc:2374] Error updating Geometry Config widget: 'plane' not found

I've ticketed issue #1769

pull_request.title: Add Insert tab to model editor

pullrequest.title: Add Insert tab to model editor

content.raw:
I think there's an issue editing links of nested models. I think it shouldn't be possible to edit them, right?

1. Insert a beer can
1. Double click the beer on the 3D view, a link inspector opens
1. Change the collision to a box and apply, the can moves and the collision changes.
1. Save the model, the saved model has a cylinder as collision.
content.html:
I think there's an issue editing links of nested models. I think it shouldn't be possible to edit them, right?

  1. Insert a beer can
  2. Double click the beer on the 3D view, a link inspector opens
  3. Change the collision to a box and apply, the can moves and the collision changes.
  4. Save the model, the saved model has a cylinder as collision.

pullrequest.title: Add Insert tab to model editor

content.raw:
- Having thumbnails would be nice. We talked about grabbing the thumbnails from the PropShop so the first step would be to get the Propshop ready... I am currently just reusing the Insert tab that we have in the normal simulation mode. As for which tab to use as default - if I were to make something from the ground up then the Insert tab, but if I just wanted to edit an existing model then maybe the Settings tab.. So no strong preference here. 

- For advanced users they may want to know since their inspectors will be different. For first time users who want to just create something quickly, it may not matter.
content.html:
• Having thumbnails would be nice. We talked about grabbing the thumbnails from the PropShop so the first step would be to get the Propshop ready... I am currently just reusing the Insert tab that we have in the normal simulation mode. As for which tab to use as default - if I were to make something from the ground up then the Insert tab, but if I just wanted to edit an existing model then maybe the Settings tab.. So no strong preference here.

  • For advanced users they may want to know since their inspectors will be different. For first time users who want to just create something quickly, it may not matter.

pull_request.title: Add Insert tab to model editor

pullrequest.title: Add Insert tab to model editor

content.raw:
Thanks for the info.

• I'm torn on the order of the tabs. Ideally, the Insert tab would have thumbnails of each model to make it look more Palette-like. The alphabetized list is a bit overwhelming and requires quite a bit of reading and searching to find the right thing. It would be great if the insert tab resembled the gzweb insert menu with an option to toggle between list view and thumbnail view (à la the Mac Finder: https://cdn.tutsplus.com/mac/authors/legacy/Josh%20Johnson/2012/07/13/findertips-5.jpg). This is still a long ways off, right? In either case, I would put the Insert tab as default, but that might be the right choice only for very beginners. It's the tab that is most understandable and relatable. The Settings are not too relevant to total novices. I can't judge how annoying it would be for users who want Settings to always have to click to that tab. So, I'd personally put the Insert tab as default, but I would also understand if you all think it's more convenient to have Settings as default. 

• Does it matter if the user knows the difference between single- and multi-link models? How will it affect them?
content.html:
Thanks for the info.

• I'm torn on the order of the tabs. Ideally, the Insert tab would have thumbnails of each model to make it look more Palette-like. The alphabetized list is a bit overwhelming and requires quite a bit of reading and searching to find the right thing. It would be great if the insert tab resembled the gzweb insert menu with an option to toggle between list view and thumbnail view (à la the Mac Finder: https://cdn.tutsplus.com/mac/authors/legacy/Josh%20Johnson/2012/07/13/findertips-5.jpg). This is still a long ways off, right? In either case, I would put the Insert tab as default, but that might be the right choice only for very beginners. It's the tab that is most understandable and relatable. The Settings are not too relevant to total novices. I can't judge how annoying it would be for users who want Settings to always have to click to that tab. So, I'd personally put the Insert tab as default, but I would also understand if you all think it's more convenient to have Settings as default.

• Does it matter if the user knows the difference between single- and multi-link models? How will it affect them?

content.raw:
- regarding the second bullet point - yes, when users insert a simple shape from the top half of the Insert tab they are inserted as links whereas models inserted from the list of models (bottom half) are models (assembly of links).

Screenshot:

![model_editor_insert.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/288092102-model_editor_insert.png)
content.html:
• regarding the second bullet point - yes, when users insert a simple shape from the top half of the Insert tab they are inserted as links whereas models inserted from the list of models (bottom half) are models (assembly of links).

pull_request.title: Add Insert tab to model editor

pullrequest.title: Add Insert tab to model editor

content.raw:
* Hrm, good question. For me personally, the insert menu would be more appealing as default because it's easier to understand what it is. The scene tree is potentially overwhelming for new users. On the other hand, most of the control is in the scene tree, so perhaps that's what people want to see most often. One day when we have customizable configurations, this can be a user-selected parameter. Is there a way to see a screenshot of what the insert tab looks like in this PR?

* Do you mean that the custom and simple shapes are single-link, whereas the other models are multi-link?
content.html:
• Hrm, good question. For me personally, the insert menu would be more appealing as default because it's easier to understand what it is. The scene tree is potentially overwhelming for new users. On the other hand, most of the control is in the scene tree, so perhaps that's what people want to see most often. One day when we have customizable configurations, this can be a user-selected parameter. Is there a way to see a screenshot of what the insert tab looks like in this PR?

  • Do you mean that the custom and simple shapes are single-link, whereas the other models are multi-link?
